posts.caption:
How do you start your very first Data science project? ğŸ“ˆâ €
â €
â˜‘ Pick your dataâ €
â €
There are thousands, if not millions, of data sets on the web. Find a data set that interests you about a topic you are passionate about. I have an aggregated list of data repositories you can explore (link in my bio)â €
â €
â˜‘ Conduct an Exploratory Data Analysis(EDA)â €
â €
Once you have your data set, load it up into Python/R/whatever and start exploring. What relationships exist within your data? What variables are of interest to you? Is there an outcome variable you would like to predict? What are some tools you might want to use to extract insights from your data? â €
â €
â˜‘ Ask questionsâ €
â €
Based on the results of your EDA, what might be some business relevant questions you could answer in an analysis? What insights would you want to gain to help make business decisions using this data? â €
â €
Pro Tip: It's always a good idea to ask general questions first and as you get more familiar with your data, update those initial questions into more precise questions.â €
â €
â˜‘ Get to workâ €
â €
Start researching and coding solutions to the questions you are interested in solving. Feel free to ask more questions as new insights reveal themselves to you in your analysis. Let your curiosity and intuition drive you.â €
â €
â˜‘ Create a final report of your findingsâ €
â €
Once you feel like you've answered your questions to the best of your abilities, it's time to communicate your findings into a nice final report. Be sure to include visualizations you made, any statistical tests you used, the models you created as well as the final results of your analysis. It's also worth including how your project could be improved in the future and what additional resources might be helpful.â €
â €
Don't worry about being perfect with your first project. No one's going to see it. Just get into the routine of building projects from start to finish. As you do more and more projects, you'll analytical skills and confidence levels will skyrocketğŸš€â €
â €
Did I miss anything? What else would you advise to someone making their very first Data Science project?
posts.author: keesh_codes

posts.caption:
119/366 New task ğŸ”¥

Today during my internship I started working on the realization of a new project, after the conception of the relational model. I have to import more than 20,000 lines of Excel files in a Postgresql database ğŸ˜¬

posts.caption:
Small progress today, I woke up with a migraine and took the morning off... because well... scr*w headaches. ğŸ‘‹ğŸ”¥
.
This afternoon was more productive. I added 3 new templates in the content creation module for YT Tracker to please subscribers with a small addition until I work on bigger features. .
Going back into this old module I havenâ€™t touched in months made me realize that part of the app are aging... and could use a little facelift. Itâ€™s fine for now and will be for a while but I had a few ideas to make things look much neater. .
Work is never really over... I have to set my own limits and pacing it out is the key. Users donâ€™t see all the things I have in mind and could do (well unless theyâ€™re reading me on here... hello ğŸ¥³âœŒï¸). So itâ€™s fine to keep ideas for later. ğŸ¤“ğŸ˜‡ .
Tomorrow... final touch, one more template and I ship! Itâ€™s been long enough since the last build uploaded to App Store Connect and my other apps also deserve my attention. ğŸ’ªğŸ‰
.

posts.caption:
Is computer science hard to learn? ğŸ¤”
â€¢
â€¢
I often receive this question and obviously the answer can't be yes or no. Like any other career, you won't find it hard to learn if you are passionate about it. Without any doubt, this unwritten rule successfully applies in the computer engineering field as well. If you want to find out if it is hard to learn programming, just don't waste more time and start doing something. Nowadays, there are plenty of resources online, so if you were thinking about making this step, don't wait anymore. Do it now! ğŸ‘ŒğŸ»

Happy Monday! It's <insert day> of the quarantine. I honestly don't know what day of the quarantine it is! As I was sitting here working, I started to think of pros and cons of my time in quarantine.
.
ğŸ‘ Pros:
ğŸ“Œ Work Productivity (Woot no meetings!)
ğŸ“Œ Learning - I've taken some time to read and better myself (personally & professionally)
ğŸ“Œ Less Stress
ğŸ“Œ Food! (Unlimited snacks ğŸ˜‚)
.
ğŸ‘Cons:
ğŸ“Œ I can't stop eating snacks ğŸ˜­
ğŸ“Œ I really need a haircut ğŸ˜«
ğŸ“Œ Work/Life balance (I spend to much time in my home office)
ğŸ“Œ Human interaction (I might miss my coworkers a tiny bit ğŸ˜‚)
.
â“ How are you handling the quarantine? Drop a comment below of some pros/cons.
.

Happy weekend! Do you have some special weekend activities? ğŸ”
â€¢
â€¢
Before the #quarantine I used to have a plan for almost every weekend. I liked to travel, have fun and spend time with my loved ones. I didn't usually stay a lot home at the end of the week. Now, every day has the same pattern, so I don't really notice that it is weekend. Do you feel the same? Stay safe and don't forget to relex!

posts.caption:
Day{ 78 ... 84 /300}[EN] #300daysofcode
ğŸ§  Steve Wozniak once said, ( â€œIf you love what you do and are willing to do what it takes, it's within your reach. And it'll be worth every minute you spend alone at night, thinking and thinking about what it is you want to design or build. It'll be worth it, I promise.â€)
.
coding is not all the time looking happy. It is actually looking like this and thinking: why the hell my doesnâ€™t my code work? Where does this bug come from now? Why is my code behaving weird?! How do I make it now? And a lot of other questions.
We are always smiling for the picture but the reality is not always that.
.
We all have problems, difficulties and moments of doubt. And it is all ok! Because people who code are people who solve problems and overcome their doubts! Our best friends are Google, Stackoverflow, Dev Tools, console.log and background-color: balck ğŸ¤ªğŸ¤ª In the end, we are able to build great things!
How do you deal with your problems while coding? Do you have a lot of these moments or not so much? What is your experience with this all?

posts.caption:
Happy Monday! I hope everyone is starting the week strong! ğŸ’ªğŸ‰ This past few days I have been working and progress on my recipe app. I feel that functionality is about 80% done. I remember when I first started learning fullstack I thought it was really challenging but it turns out... it's not hard at all! I have learned so much already.
My next steps are unmounting my components to clear the state.
I also have rethought about how my data is structured when the user enters the instructions and ingredients. So I'll be changing somethings around. I hope I will be able to deploy the first version this week.
I am feeling good and productive! I hope you guys are too! Have a great week and let me know what you're doing today? ğŸ‘‡ â€¢
